I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  In the proposed project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a $50 million 
sovereign guaranteed loan to the Regional Development Bank (RDB), a state-owned bank whose 
mission is to strengthen the living standards of the rural population by providing affordable and 
accessible credit facilities. The proposed project will provide long-term financing totaling $50 
million worth of loans to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) outside Colombo and will be 
structured to provide regulatory capital that would leverage an additional $533 million of lending.  
 
2.  Research from 2017 confirms earlier findings that access to finance is a key barrier to Sri 
Lankan entrepreneurs.1 Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) face constraints 
on affordable financing on the demand side, such as poor commercial viability and difficulty 
meeting financial institutions’ lending requirements, and on the supply side, such as financial 
institutions having operations poorly designed for MSMEs and an overreliance on collateral-based 
loans. These constrains are even greater for MSMEs that are led by women or located in rural 
areas. Therefore, in addition to ADB’s ongoing projects in the MSME sector, the government 
requested ADB to enhance MSMEs’ access to finance by strengthening RDB.2  
 
3.  The proposed project’s impact will be MSME access to finance enhanced. The outcome 
will be RDB’s strengthened capacity to serve its MSME clients. Project outputs will be (i) RDB’s 
operations expanded, (ii) RDB’s operational capacity strengthened, and (iii) the capacity of MSEs 
to access financial services enhanced.            
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will address the supply-side and demand-side 
issues that hinder MSMEs’ access to finance by (i) strengthening the capacity of RDB to serve its 
MSME clients in rural areas and improve the enabling environment for MSMEs’ access to finance, 
which will ensure financial sustainability beyond the project implementation period; and (ii) 
strengthening the capacity of MSMEs at the policy level and individual enterprise level. Although 
the project is a financial intermediation loan to be onlent to revenue generating MSE subprojects, 
the transaction TA aims to transfer knowledge and enhance skills in RDB, MSMEs, and the 
government. These activities cannot be easily monetized or structured on a cost recovery basis. 
 
The government has confirmed this transaction TA through an aide-mémoire.3  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  The current growth of RDB cannot be sustained because of a capital shortfall. Although 
ADB’s loan, which will be structured as tier 2 capital, will provide some relief, RDB needs to ensure 
its financial sustainability beyond the loan implementation period. Therefore, RDB’s institutional 
strengthening measures have been agreed between RDB and ADB.4 The following transaction 
                                                
1  International Finance Corporation. 2017. MSME Finance Gap. Washington, DC. 
2  Summary of Asian Development Bank’s Support for Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Finance Sector in Sri Lanka 
(accessible from the list of supplementary documents in Appendix 2 of the report and recommendation of the 
President).  
3  The government’s aide-mémoire was received in September 2018. The TA first appeared in the business 
opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 September 2018. 
4  Appendix of the Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2 of the 
report and recommendation of the President).

2 
TA outputs are aligned with the project’s outputs and primarily designed to support RDB in 
achieving these institutional strengthening measures, which could lead to ADB’s Board approving 
additional financing.    
 
6.  Output 1: Regional Development Bank’s operations expanded. The TA will support 
RDB in  
(i)  strengthening its project management unit, and   
(ii)  restructuring and relaunching RDB’s deposit mobilization program, which includes 
a women-targeted deposit product, to increase its retail saving deposits and 
decrease its cost of funds. 
 
7.  Output 2: Regional Development Bank’s operational capacity strengthened. The TA 
will support RDB in  
(i)   formulating a board strategy focusing on outreach to MSEs, including those led by 
women;  
(ii)   strengthening market risk management to more effectively address liquidity risk, 
interest rate risk, and foreign exchange risk, including upgrading risk management 
policies and improving board reporting;  
(iii)  strengthening credit operations and risk management by (a) upgrading the loan 
origination system with an information technology solution, (b) upgrading the credit 
scoring system, (c) revising the credit policy framework, and (d) providing loan 
officers with credit appraisal training; and    
 (v)   strengthening safeguard management, including establishing and operationalizing 
an environmental and social safeguard management system.   
 
8.  Output 3: Capacity of micro and small enterprises to access financial services 
increased. The TA will develop supporting infrastructure to increase the capacity of MSEs to 
access finance by  
(i)  providing business development training (including financial literacy training) to at 
least 500 RDB women clients;  
(ii)  developing  and  implementing  a  train-the-trainers  program  on  MSE  business 
development and financial literacy for at least 60 RDB staff, of which at least 30 
should be women; and      
(iii)   preparing a white paper on evaluating the effectiveness of government MSME 
support programs with an emphasis on women borrowers.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,050,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB and the 
remainder  will  be  in-kind  contribution  from  RDB  and  the  government  (para  11).  The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
10.  The following items are ineligible expenditures under the TA funded by JFPR: (i) purchase 
of  vehicles,  (ii)  salaries  for  civil  servants,  (iii)  any  foreign  travel,  (iv)  scholarships  or  long 
internships, (v) detailed engineering design, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) 
those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities 
List.5 
 
                                                
5   ADB. 2011. Cost Sharing and Expenditure Eligibility, Compendium of Staff Instructions. Manila.

3 
11.  The implementing agencies will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff,  office  accommodation,  office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA.
